steps.title: Apply aloe vera to your face.
steps.content: Apply aloe vera to your face. The aloe vera plant has many therapeutic properties, including treating burns, cuts, and infections. It is also effective on oily skin and acne. Cut an aloe leaf in half and squeeze out the gel. Apply the gel evenly over your face. Allow the gel to dry. After it dries, rinse it off with cool water. This can be repeated two or three times a day.

steps.title: Apply yogurt to your face.
steps.content: Apply yogurt to your face. Yogurt helps open up pores, exfoliate the skin, and absorb excess oil. Take one tablespoon of plain yogurt and spread it evenly over your face. Leave the yogurt on for 15 minutes, then rinse off with cold water. Repeat once a day.

steps.title: Rub cucumbers on your face.
steps.content: Rub cucumbers on your face. Cucumbers are often applied during facials and spa treatments because of their soothing properties. They contain vitamins and minerals that can help fight swelling, redness, and excess oil. Slice up a fresh cucumber and rub the slices on your face. Leave this on your face overnight, rinsing with warm water in the morning. Repeat daily.

steps.title: Avoid harsh soaps and creams.
steps.content: Avoid harsh soaps and creams. Any products containing alcohol or other harsh chemicals can irritate your face. This irritation could lead to more oil production and make the problem worse.

steps.title: Avoid over-washing your face.
steps.content: Avoid over-washing your face. Though you may think that the more you wash your face the better, this is not the case. Like with harsh chemicals, excessive washing will lead to irritation and can make your symptoms worse. You should wash your face no more than two times daily.

steps.title: Stop using heavy cosmetics.
steps.content: Stop using heavy cosmetics. These products can clog your pores, which will trap oil and dirt in the skin and make acne symptoms worse.

steps.title: Change any towels or pads you use on your face every day.
steps.content: Change any towels or pads you use on your face every day. Oil, dirt, and bacteria get trapped on these products and you can then spread them all over your face.

steps.title: Use a gentle facial cleanser twice a day.
steps.content: Use a gentle facial cleanser twice a day. Most dermatologists agree that cleansing the skin is the best way to reduce oil. [1] X Research source Make sure to use a gentle, pH balanced cleanser rather than regular soap. Most soaps are highly alkaline and strip the natural acid mantle from the skin leaving it vulnerable to bacteria. Products containing benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, glycolic acid, or beta-hydroxy acid are often considered best. These are slightly acidic, however, so start off with only a small amount to make sure your skin doesn't have an adverse reaction. When washing your face, make sure you use warm water, not hot. Hot water can further irritate the skin. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use a toner free of alcohol or acetone.
steps.content: Use a toner free of alcohol or acetone. Place a few drops on a clean, natural cotton pad and wipe it gently over the affected area. Toners can be harsh on skin, so dermatologists often recommend only using them on oily parts of your face rather than the whole face. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Moisturize your skin.
steps.content: Moisturize your skin. While it may seem counterproductive, oil and moisture are two different things. Even oily skin can be dehydrated and requires moisturizer to stay healthy. Make sure to use a light, oil-free moisturizer. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Use blotting papers.
steps.content: Use blotting papers. This is a quick, effective solution to soak up excess oil. They won't cut down on your skin's oil production though, so this treatment should be paired with a cleansing regimen for the best results. Make sure you don't rub your skin with blotting papers. This can spread dirt and cause irritation. Instead, just gently press the paper down on your skin and hold it there for 15 to 20 seconds. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Use a clay mask.
steps.content: Use a clay mask. Masks help draw out dirt and oil, keeping pores clean. These products can also dry out the skin, however, so make sure you don't overuse them. Once a week should be the maximum usage. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Apply an oil-free, mineral powder makeup base for the daytime.
steps.content: Apply an oil-free, mineral powder makeup base for the daytime. Use powder blush rather than cream blush and powder eye shadows rather than cream eye shadows. A dusting of a translucent powder can be applied two or three times during the day after blotting the face with a tissue to remove any excess oil.

steps.title: Visit your dermatologist.
steps.content: Visit your dermatologist. OTC treatments may not work for everyone, and you might need something stronger. Talk to your dermatologist and explain your symptoms and what you've already tried. She can then recommend a variety of other treatments for you.

steps.title: Use prescription-strength topical treatments.
steps.content: Use prescription-strength topical treatments. If OTC topicals aren't helping your oily skin, stronger treatments are available by prescription. These creams usually contain tretinoin, adapalene, or tazarotene, and work by shrinking pores and reducing oil production. [7] X Research source Be sure to follow all instructions when using prescription creams. Used improperly, they can further irritate your skin.

steps.title: Try a laser treatment.
steps.content: Try a laser treatment. Lasers can be used to shrink pores and reduce oil production.

steps.title: Take Accutane.
steps.content: Take Accutane. This is a prescription oral medication. It works by shrinking the oil glands, cutting the production of sebum. It is most often prescribed to treat serious acne that does not respond to other treatments. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Try a chemical peel.
steps.content: Try a chemical peel. With this treatment, a chemical is applied to the face that removes the top layer of skin. It is used to treat wrinkles, sun damage, and some forms of acne. [9] X Research source
